[New Zealand](/wiki/Buddhism_in_New_Zealand) - [Russia](/wiki/Buddhism_in_Russia) - [Singapore](/wiki/Buddhism_in_Singapore) - [US](/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_United_States) - [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Buddhism_in_Sri_Lanka) - [Taiwan](/wiki/Buddhism_in_Taiwan) - [Thailand](/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand) - [Tibet](/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism) - [Vietnam](/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam) - Buddhism portal - v - t - e **Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple** ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 觀音堂佛祖廟; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Guānyīn Táng Fózǔ Miào*; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *Koan-im Tông Hu̍t-chó͘ Biō*) is a traditional Chinese temple situated at 178 [Waterloo Street](/wiki/Waterloo_Street) in Singapore. The temple is of significance to the Buddhist community among [Chinese Singaporeans](/wiki/Chinese_Singaporeans), and is believed to bring worshippers good luck after praying to the [Kuan Yin](/wiki/Guanyin) or [Avalokiteśvara](/wiki/Avalokite%C5%9Bvara), the **Goddess of Mercy**. The temple is also involved in charity work, contributing to several health and educational organisations. The Kwan Im Temple and the nearby [Sri Krishnan Temple](/wiki/Sri_Krishnan_Temple) are known for having evolved a [social practice](/wiki/Sociality) termed "cross-worshipping", where many devotees of either temple also worship at the other. This practice is commonly seen as a microcosm of Singapore's multi-religious society. ## History and architecture According to inscriptions at the temple, the temple started in 1884 when a company, Chen Liang Cheng (陈两成), donated a parcel of land to build a temple. In 1895, the temple was renovated and in 1980, it went through a major expansion and renovation. The 1980 expansion costs $5 million dollars and when completed, the temple stands on an area of 1500 square meters, almost double the size of the original temple. ## Worship The temple's main worship is [Cundi](/wiki/Cundi_(Buddhism)), a manifestation of [Guanyin](/wiki/Guanyin). It also worship [Damo](/wiki/Bodhidharma) and [Hua Tuo](/wiki/Hua_Tuo). A statue of [Tathagata Buddha](/wiki/Tathagata_Buddha) is also placed behind Kuan Yin. On top of the altar there is also the [Four Heavenly Kings](/wiki/Four_Heavenly_Kings). In the traditional folk religious landscape, a practice of "cross-worshipping" has developed between devotees of the [Sri Krishnan Temple](/wiki/Sri_Krishnan_Temple) and the Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple, where many devotees of either temple also worship or pay their respects at the other temple. Both temples are of [polytheistic religious nature](/wiki/Polytheism): [Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism) and the [Chinese traditional religion](/wiki/Chinese_folk_religion_in_Southeast_Asia), and this practice is commonly seen as a microcosm of Singapore's multi-religious society. In the late 1980s, a seller of [Hainanese chicken rice](/wiki/Hainanese_chicken_rice) donated a large urn, worth approximately [S](/wiki/Singapore_dollar)$1,000, to the Sri Krishnan Temple, to hold the joss sticks of Chinese worshippers. The [Sri Krishnan Temple](/wiki/Sri_Krishnan_Temple) administration has added a statue of [Guanyin](/wiki/Guanyin) inside their temple and designated a zone within the temple compound for Chinese worshippers to burn joss sticks. - National Heritage Board (2002). *Singapore's 100 Historic Places*. Eastern University Press. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 981-4068-23-3. - Edwards, Norman; Keys, Peter (1988). *Singapore: A Guide to Buildings, Streets, Places*. Times Books International. title: Kwan Im Thong Hood Cho Temple
